brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides a rule that checks if an all-args constructor exists for @lombok.Builder in JPA entities.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: This rule, named 'lombok-builder-all-args-constructor', iterates over all classes in the project. If a class is annotated with '@lombok.Builder', it asserts that there exists a constructor method in the class that takes all fields of the class as arguments. If such a constructor does not exist, it generates a message indicating that the class does not have a proper all-args constructor.
PRE_model_validation: The rule is syntactically correct according to the Rule-Specific Language (RSL) syntax. It uses only the built-in functions provided, and does not introduce any new functions. The rule checks for the existence of an all-args constructor in classes annotated with '@lombok.Builder', which aligns with the requirement.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/lombok-builder
Summary: This page provides a comprehensive guide on using Lombok's @Builder annotation. It explains the need for a constructor with all arguments when using @Builder, which is what our rule checks for.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40620000/lombok-builder-and-jpa-default-constructor
Summary: This StackOverflow discussion highlights issues that can arise when using Lombok's @Builder annotation with JPA entities, specifically the need for a default constructor. Our rule complements this by checking for an all-args constructor.
